Posts.Content:
Radiologists become concerned when they see clusters of microcacifications. They are sometimes, but not always, an indication of cancer, usually early stage or "in situ" cancer. More often than not, they are benign. So try not to stress too much! 
If you have microcalcifications, then you should definitely have regular mammograms. Microcalcifications are one of the few things they can identify as a possible precursor to breast cancer. 
Hope you get benign results!
Hugs,
BEV

Only your doctor can tell you why they didn't investigate further when you brought it to their attention before. But I would sure be asking that question!
On the bright side, it probably is nothing. Callbacks for more pictures happen often. Even after having breast cancer, I've had callbacks for more pictures, and it turned out to be nothing. So try not to stress about
 it for now. 
Take care, and let us know how it goes.

Posts.Content:
Of course you are going to worry! And of course, it is a good things that they are going to find out what this is. An ultrasound is done if they suspect something they see on the mammogram may be a cyst. An ultrasound will tell if what they're looking at is fluid-filled. Some fluid-filled cysts have some "stuff" in them. If that is the case, then there is a slight possibility that the "stuff" can have cancer cells. If what they're seeing isn't fluid-filled, that doesn't mean it is cancer. It just means it is not a cyst. Even with all the technology they have today, more often than not, a biopsy is negative for cancer. Hope yours turns out to be nothing. I think a biopsy scar is a small price to pay for peace of mind.

Posts.Title: Small cluster of microcalcification

Posts.Content:
On the subject of dense breasts...the younger you are, the more likely the breast tissue will read as "dense," as I understand it. I have never heard that it increases your chances for breast cancer, but I'm not a medical person. Dense breast tissue shows up white on a mammogram, and because breast cancer also shows as a white mass, it is difficult to "find" breast cancers in dense breast tissue on a mammogram. This is why up to 30 percent of all breast cancers are missed on mammograms.
I think the "calcium deposits" you referred to are probably microcalcifications. This shows up as if salt has been sprinkled on the mammogram. Lots of women have them, and they do warrant watching. If the microcalcifications start to show as a cluster in a small area, this can be an indication of breast cancer, but not always. 
With dense breast tissue, they probably want to look at a particular area closer, to determine if there is a cluster of microcalcifications, or if there is just a density in the breast tissue. 
I had just been diagnosed with two types of invasive breast cancer when I got a letter stating that my mammogram results were normal. And a few years later, I got called back for a "mass" in my remaining breast....waited for weeks for the second appointment, had compression views, and they were normal. No mass, no cancer. Mammograms are not perfect. So my advice would be not to worry too much until you have the next tests done. And we'll be hoping they are normal.
Let us know how it goes!
Hugs...

Posts.Title: Stage IV Breast Cancer Survivors?

Posts.Content:
Hi, Matt. I've never taken either drug, so I don't speak from personal experience here. But I was wondering if your wife is being put on other drugs, as well? For instance, is she taking a taxane for treatment, such as Taxotere? This can cause joint pain. And if she is taking a biphosphonate, such as Zometa, these can, especially initially, cause bone and joint pain. So it may not be simply the switch from Femara to Tamoxifen that is causing the increase in pain. Just something else to consider. I know tamoxifen works differently from Femara, and it is often preferred over tamoxifen because it typically has fewer side effects. 
Really sorry to hear about
 your wife's mets. We never like to hear that someone is having to tangle with breast cancer... especially a second (or third or fourth, as some of our member do) time around.

Hope your itchies are totally unrelated to cancer.
Let us know how it goes for you.

Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Stage I

Posts.Content:
I had fibrocystic breast disease for years before I was diagnosed with breast cancer. At times, the pain was almost unbearable. When I found the cancerous lumps, they were different from the fcbd lumps. They were painless and unchanging. Even my husband could tell the difference. That was what sent me to the doctor. I will say, however, that some women do report pain in their breasts with breast cancer, but that is rare. I have never heard or read that there is a relationship between fcbd and breast cancer. Lots of women get call backs that turn out to be nothing. After my initial dx, I was called back for a "mass" in my remaining breast. I was thoroughly prepared for a cancer dx, and you could have knocked me over with a feather when they said there was nothing there. The "mass" was a result of the way the tissue was pushed together in the mammo. Compression views showed normal tissue and no mass. I was on cloud nine! So it could be nothing. Try not to worry too much about
 it. I had to wait 6 long weeks to get my follow-up views done. 
Good luck with your follow-up. Hopefully, it will be nothing. And my sympathies with the fcbd. I know how absolutely miserable it can be, and none of the "remedies," such as avoid caffeine, etc.. helped at all. I had a friend who had elective mastectomies with reconstructive surgery, not because of cancer, but because of fcbd. She has never regretted that decision.
Take care, and good luck... Let us know how it goes!
Hugs...
BEV

 what would happen to them if I died of this darned disease. I had lost my own mother to cancer when I was 7, and the thought of leaving my girls without a mom... Anyway, it's been 17 years since I was dx'ed. My girls are grown and gone. I have a beautiful granddaughter who is the light of my life. And I'm "no evidence of disease" since mastectomy and chemo. Your prognosis is so good! So try to count your blessings that this hasn't had time to grow into an invasive cancer that would require more treatment than a lumpectomy and an aromatase inhibitor.
Take care, and try to think about
 how good this really is!

One of the benefits of some antidepressants... they can help relieve the hot flashes associated with menopause. Posts.Title: After excisional breast biopsy - scar tissue?

Posts.Content:
MMckay
LCIS is early stage, so there is not a clear consensus on whether or not chemo is necessary. Most doctors, I think, like to do radiation with a lumpectomy, as a precautionary measure. If there is a stray cancer cell or two after surgery, then radiation will take care of it. The tamoxifen is used if the cancer is ER/PR positive. It is a hormone blocker and keeps hormones from "feeding" any stray cancer cells. Tamoxifen doesn't typically cause you to lose your hair. Taxanes, like Taxotere, will cause hair loss, but they are true chemo drugs. 
Of course this is all scary! And you have every right to be worried. You are so young, and you've just found out you have cancer! But the good news is, they have caught it early, and it is as treatable as a breast cancer can be. So try to keep that in mind when you are getting overworked about
 the whole thing. 
Let us know how things are going...
Hugs...

Posts.Title: Tamoxifen Side Effects

Posts.Content:
Tracey, I had all of those side effects, except for the headaches, not from radiation or tamoxifen, but from chemotherapy. Chemo put me into menopause at 36, and I immediately started to gain weight, experience horrible (and I agree with you... horrible is the perfect word), sleepless nights, and no energy. The doctor tried several different medications, none of which helped at all. Finally, they put me on effexor, and within days, my symptoms began to abate. Different anti-depressants work for menopausal symptoms for different people. If zoloft doesn't work for you, ask your doctor if you can try a different one. I've actually had fewer headaches since I lost all my estrogen... which leaves me to believe that they were hormone-related. 
Hugs...

Posts.Title: DCIS Diagnosis/Stage IV Breast Cancer

Posts.Content:
Wow. This is a tough one. If I were you, I would insist on going to a breast specialist (here in the US, we have "breast centers") to figure all of this out. Cysts are fluid filled. Tumors are solid. So on an ultrasound, the two do not look alike. Some cysts, complex cysts, have fluid in them, but they also have "junk" in them. It is rare, but sometimes these cysts have some cancer cells in them. Often they aspirate and look at the "junk" to see if they find any cancer cells. Biopsy is always the surest way to rule out cancer, though. 
As far as dense breasts go, I also had dense breasts. My first mammo came back negative for any signs of cancer and stated breast density as their CYB clause. Fortunately, my doctor insisted on biopsies, which even the surgeon thought was unnecessary, but agreed to because my doctor insisted. I had two different types of invasive breast cancer. Surgeon also said he didn't feel anything "suspicious" in axillary nodes (I had thought they were "just cysts"), but had three nodes that were cancerous. 
So if you are uncomfortable with the way things are going, I would encourage to look further until you get answers that you can live with. I was 36 at the time. Had my family doctor not been as proactive as he was, I don't know how many years I would have had before my cancers were discovered, and I seriously doubt that I would be alive today to be answering your post. 
I don't intend to scare you. But you can't let doctors intimidate you! This is your body, your health, and ultimately your life we are talking about
 here! 
Let me know how things go. 
Hugs...
BEV

You need to find a doctor who will listen to you and help you figure out how to deal with this, rather than brush you off. Do you have a breast center near where you live?

Posts.Title: looking for opinions on my mammagram/ultrasound findings

Posts.Content:
I didn't mean to make you feel more nervous than you were before. LCIS is an acronym for "Lobular Carcinoma in situ." I think in one of her books, Susan Love refers to LCIS as "pre-cancer." The abnormal cells are contained within the lobule (usually aren't any cells contained within the lobules). While this may not be considered a "real" cancer, it definitely puts you at higher risk for developing breast cancer. And many doctors want to treat as a very early cancer for that reason. Thus the tamoxifen, which blocks the hormones that feed breast cancers. Does that make sense?
Sorry if I confused you.

Posts.Title: Multiple complex cysts

Posts.Content:
Lumps and bumps in your breasts are to be expected and are usually just normal breast tissue. At 16, you should be learning what is normal for you. You may find lumps and tenderness that are tied to your menstrual cycle and come and go at the same time every month. These are normal. Cysts are not uncommon, either. They can be aspirated, but they may come back. So if this is a cyst, and they use a needle to remove the fluid, don't be surprised or worried if it comes back. It is highly unlikely that you have breast cancer. 80% of all lumps that make it to biopsy are benign. At 16, I'm sure the likelihood is much less than that, even. 
But good for you that you are willing to take your concerns to your doctor and do something about
 it! Most of the time when we have young girls come visit with concerns such as yours, they are either afraid or embarrassed to talk to their doctors. So keep being proactive! Get to know what is normal for you, and if you find something suspicious, trust me, you will know that it is different.
Hope this helps.

Posts.Title: IBC or not??? these dr's

Posts.Content:
Hi, DSB. With your family history, I would think you WOULD be able to find a surgeon who would do a prophylactic double mastectomy, and I would think your insurance would cover it. This is obviously not a cosmetic surgery, and there is reason to believe that this might significantly reduce your chances of getting breast cancer in the future, which would save the insurance company $$$. Hysterectomies to avoid future problems are pretty commonplace; if you think about
 it, the mastectomies would be no different, really. OF course, it depends on whether you have really good insurance (thank goodness if you do!), or really bad insurance (which is becoming more and more common, unfortunately!).
I don't think a needle biopsy will make any cancer that you might have spread. But I would agree with you that a surgical biopsy would be a better choice. Remove the suspicious area altogether. 
Another note: a double mastectomy will go a long way in alleviating your risk of breast cancer, that is true. But it doesn't entirely eliminate it. No matter how good the surgeon, it is impossible to remove every breast tissue cell, and those remaining cells could still develop breast cancer. Of course, your odds of that happening are very slim, but you still need to be vigilant about
 examining the breast area and have your gyn check you every year, as well.
Good luck in your quest to find the right surgeon. A good breast center would be the place to start, I would think.
Hugs...
BEV
Posts.Title: Needle biopsy

Posts.Content:
Parabens and aluminum have both been suspect. A causal link has never been established between deodorants and breast cancer. The studies that have been done haven't really proved anything. It's kind of like the study that concludes that, because people eat more ice cream in the summer and more crimes occur in the summer, ice cream consumption rates can be linked with crime. 
The study related to breast cancer and deodorants has the same flaw. They found that women who start using deodorants and shaving their armpits at an early age were more likely to develop breast cancer earlier than other women. Now, the problem with this study is this: young girls begin shaving and using deodorant when the hormones start raging... also about
 the same time they start wearing bras and start their monthly periods. We already know that early maturation is a risk factor for breast cancer, so how does that show any correlation to using deodorants? Why isn't there an increase of bilateral breast cancers? And why does this not increase the risk of developing breast cancer in men?
Anyway, I think that Arm and Hammer makes a deodorant that is free of parabens and aluminum. Secret makes a natural deodorant that uses calcium carbonate. And some people swear by Milk of Magnesia, vinegar, or alcohol. I'll stick to my Dove. :) 
Hugs...
BEV
Bev
Breast Cancer forum moderator
Posts.Title: Deodorant

Posts.Content:
Hi, K.T. Mammograms. Mammograms in younger women are not a definitive answer. Younger women have denser breast tissue, and that tissue often reads white, hiding tumors and other masses. I had a mammogram at 36 because I had two lumps in my breast. Showed no abnormalities. My doctor insisted on a biopsy. Two days after I was diagnosed with two different types of invasive breast cancer, I got a very nice letter from the hospital saying my mammogram showed no signs of cancer, and I should go back when I turned 40. Mammograms can miss as many as 30% of breast cancers. So I hope your doctor is not going only by your mammogram.
Breast cancer doesn't usually hurt. "Usually" is the key word here. Mine didn't hurt. But I know several women who did have pain as a result of there tumors. It is not that uncommon. And I don't know how breast reduction would affect that.
Chances are, your doctor is right. This is probably not cancer. But to dismiss the pain that you are experiencing simply because it is probably not breast cancer is not good enough. You could have adhesions from your reduction and your weight gain is causing the adhesions to pull. You could have some type of infection. But whatever it is, it needs to be addressed, and my personal feeling is that castor oil with heat is not going to make a big difference.
If your doctor won't get to the bottom of this, then maybe you could consult another doctor. 
Hope you get some answers!
Hugs...
BEV

Breast Cancer forum moderator

Posts.Title: (No Subject)

Posts.Content:
I agree with you. If your doctor ordered tests, I don't think the hospital should question his judgment. If I were him, I would be throwing a major fit with the technicians or radiologists who made this determination for him. At least they did an ultrasound. You are right, it is probably nothing, but here's the good news... breast cancer is a slow-growing cancer, so if there is something suspicious there, three weeks would probably be insignificant in terms of outcome. Lots of women have to wait 6 weeks or more to get a mammogram, weeks more to get a biopsy, and weeks more for surgery, even after their doctors have identified a suspicious lump.
Hope it is nothing more than inflamed tissue. And sorry you were treated so poorly! I knew a young lady who was diagnosed at 19, and she passed away at the age of 25, after a 6 year battle with the disease. So probably, this is nothing. But stay on this if you don't see improvement in the next few weeks!
Hugs...

Posts.Title: Lump

Posts.Content:
Hi Nan. I agree with you, the changes to our bodies are not always easy to live with. I remember sitting in my daughter's 8th grade graduation. I was so pissed! I was beet red from the Adriamycin, wearing a very uncomfortable wig and false eyelashes because of the chemotherapy, sweating like crazy from hot flashes, and wondering if I would live long enough to see my next one go through her 8th grade graduation, much less high school graduations. I knew full well that none of the other mothers there were wearing wigs or hot flashing or thinking about
 how long they might live. It was horrible. 
After 17 years, I'm finally letting my blonde hair grow long again. I'm really too old for it now, but really, I was afraid to let it grow long again, for fear that I would lose it all again. I saw both of my daughters graduate high school, college, and Master's programs! Looking forward to seeing my oldest get her PhD in a couple of years, even! And I've even gotten to see my first granddaughter's birth. And I have felt so blessed to have lived to see all these things come to pass in my children's lives. I don't know that all those other mothers realized how precious those moments were, as I did. Our perspectives do change!
I posted some info on antidepressants to your other post, so be sure to read that, too. Just know that, this too, shall pass. Life does get better again. 
Hugs...

Posts.Title: Do i have it or not?

Posts.Content:
Oh, I'm so sorry, dj. That really sucks, but the good news is, you've found it, and now you will be doing something about
 it. I don't think all women go to specialists. My surgeon did a lot of breast cancer surgeries, but he did other surgeries as well. I had two types of invasive cancer, so I had to have a mastectomy, but you may have the option of a lumpectomy, I don't know. So ask lots of questions about
 what type of surgery the surgeon is recommending and why. Most insurances will pay for a second opinion, in which case you could pick your own surgeon and choose the one you feel most comfortable with. It might have to be someone who is covered under your plan, depending on what kind of plan you have. If they are recommending a mastectomy, ask about
 reconstructive surgery and who they would recommend for that. You should be able to get second opinions on reconstruction as well. Most plastic surgeons will have pictures of reconstructive surgeries that they have done. Ask to see them. 
Ask what type of lymph node surgery they are recommending. Will they do a sentinel node biopsy (they inject dye and see which lymph node catches it first... they take that node and one or two others and assume they can determine lymph node invasion based on that), or will they do a traditional lymph node dissection (they take a sample of several lymph nodes and look for cancer in them.) Ask why.
If you can think of anything else, please let us know. Again, sorry you are joining our ranks, but I'm so glad you took your company's offer of a free mammogram! How old are you, BTW...

An adhesion is a band of scar tissue that binds two tissues together that should be separate. They can be very thick and fiberous, and they can be very painful. By the way, they are pretty common with implants, where adhesions form between your tissue and the implant. Some people are more prone to adhesions than others, I think. Sometimes myofacial release can help with adhesions. 
Hope this helps. Keep away from those steak knives, Stella!

Posts.Title: Do I have anything to be worried about?? Because i am WORRIED!

Posts.Content:
You can always ask for a biopsy. With a cyst, they can do a fine needle aspiration. Sometimes, a cyst will have "junk" in it. Think orange juice... without pulp is my favorite. The kind with the pulp floating around in it? Yuck! That would be a cyst with junk in it. And then, very rarely, there will be a seed that gets through the juicing process. This would be the rare cyst with junk it it that has a stray cancer cell. This is very rare, but not impossible. 6 months, in terms of breast cancer, isn't very long. The smallest mass that will be found on a mammogram would usually have to grow for another three years before it would be a palpable mass. And the cancer probably started growing years before that. So you could wait, you could ask for a fine needle aspiration, or you could ask for a biopsy. Somewhere around 80% of biopsies are benign, even with all the technology we have, but sometimes a small scar is worth you peace of mind.
Hope this helps.
Hugs...

I wish I could give you an answer, but I'm not a medical professional, and there are so many things that this could be! It doesn't necessarily have to be cancer. There are benign tumors (phyllodes tumors) that can grow very quickly. Your reference to broccoli brought that to mind, because they usually grow from a central "stalk" with a cluster of tumors at the "head." I don't think they are typically painful, but they can be very fast growing. They are also pretty rare. Even more rarely, they can be cancerous. But this could also be a lot of other things, as well. 
I hope you will go to the surgeon with a list of questions that you would like to have answered before you leave his office. Write your questions down. Take your mom or someone close to you as a second pair of ears. Sometimes they will remember things that we forget.

Posts.Content:
Hi, Cant... Pathology reports. We aren't medical professionals here, but I'll give you my thoughts on your report. First of all, the report says that "findings are consistent with an inflammatory process." This isn't the same as "inflammatory breast cancer." An inflammatory process could be any number of things, but inflammatory breast cancer is not actually an inflammatory process, as far as I know... It is called "inflammatory" because of its appearance (redness, heat, and swelling). The hyperemia is increased blood flow to the area, which is consistent with an inflammatory process. Remember, these are just my thoughts on the report. I can't say that your pathologist shares my understanding of IBC. 
Your mammogram reports indicates that there is something going on with the nipple and areola, obviously, but really doesn't indicate what they are thinking this is, although it could be a result of an inflammatory process, or it could possibly be Paget's Disease from the descript
ion. Again, just my thoughts. 
The best place to get answers is your doctor or surgeon. I'm sorry you are having such a hard time getting answers. It is really difficult to wait for answers, but when you just get answers without any explanation, that's even worse!
Questions to ask:
1) Do I have inflammatory breast cancer?
2) Do I have Paget's disease?
(If the answer is Neither, then what is the official diagnosis?)
3) Why did the surgeon say he removed an abscess, and the pathology report says there is no abscess? 
4) How do we treat this?
5) Why has it taken so long to get answers??? (That one is for me! LOL)
Again, hope you get some real answers soon.
Hugs...
BEV

Breast Cancer forum moderator

Hi, DB. I'm sure that you already know that medullary breast cancer is one of the rarer breast cancers. I'll just tell you what I know about
 them... I know that they are typically not aggressive cancers, even though they may appear to be more aggressive than they actually are. They are typically not as likely to spread as some other breast cancers. Some doctors feel that chemo and radiation are not necessary follow-up, but some doctors believe it should be done as a precaution. The key word here is "typically," and I don't know if your mom's cancer is typical for medullary breast cancer or not. Only your mom's doctors can tell you that. 
If they advise chemo and radiation, it certainly doesn't hurt to get a second opinion. Hope this helps.

Posts.Title: Romantic Relationships in Working Breast Cancer Survivors

Posts.Content:
Don't know what path you've chosen, but treating cancer, if you ask me, is a crap shoot, anyway. My best friend was diagnosed about
 a year after I was. We had very similar treatments. Her prognosis was better than mine, all things considered. Next week will be four years since we lost her. 
A friend of ours was diagnosed with colon cancer a few years ago. He underwent all the surgery and chemo, but it was a difficult battle, physically and emotionally for him. He lost his home because of the medical bills. He lost his wife, who went searching for greener pastures...a woman he thought was his soulmate. To tell the truth, I think he'd have preferred the cancer had killed him, because he has not heart for living anymore.
We all just do what we think is best for us. Some of us get lucky. Some of us don't. Chemo, you know, isn't a cure for cancer. The hope is that chemo will buy five extra years of health. For me, 6 months for 5 more years meant seeing my daughters graduate high school. A small price to pay. I watched the birth of my first grandbaby a couple of years after that. Last month, I got to see my oldest graduate college. What a bonus! Those six months I gave up have been worth the price over and again. 
My brother just got married this last month. Also a cancer survivor. Double bonus! 
Anyway, just want you to know that, whatever path you choose, it is the best one for you because you chose it. Don't let other people's paths confuse you.
This board is a give and take kind of place. Sometimes we give, and sometimes we take. And sometimes we just have fun!!!
Take care...
Bev

I had cysts as a teenager/ young woman. There were times when they were so painful that I would have to hold my chest when I got up in the mornings until I could get a snug bra on. I've had a friend who had prophylactic mastectomies as a young woman because of her pain. Typically, these cysts are not associated with breast cancer.  losing your breast, it's about
 losing your life, as well. I've made it cancer free for almost 17 years. My best friend was diagnosed a couple of years after I was. She lost her battle with cancer. I've been involved in breast cancer boards for many years, and a large group of us have become close as a result. We lose friends every year. My own mom died of cancer when I was 7, so when I was dx'ed at 36, I wasn't thinking about

Posts.Title: IM 33 YEARS OLD. ULTRASOUND AND MAMMO NOW REFERRED TO A GENERAL SURGEON-CONCERNED HELP!

Posts.Content:
The bones are one of the favored sites for metastatic breast cancer. Breast cancer cells also find the liver, the lungs, and the brain to be good hosts. By examining cells, they will be able to determine if this is breast cancer that has gone to the bones, or if it is an actual bone cancer. So sorry your sister is having to go through this. Let us know what they find out in further testing.
Hugs...
BEV
Bev
Breast Cancer forum moderator
Posts.Title: breat cancer has now spread to bone...throughout body

Posts.Content:
Hi, Lisa. The good news is that you have had regular mammograms. Microcalcifications are fairly common. When they see clusters, sometimes, but not always by any means, it can be an indication of cancer. Usually if it is cancerous, it is very early stage, especially if you have had regular mammograms. 
Listen, a week is really good! I had already had breast cancer and a single mastectomy when my mammogram on my remaining breast showed a "mass." It took 6 weeks for me to get an appointment to have follow-up imaging! 
I had one biopsy done where I found out while I was still on the table that my lumps were cancerous. I had another biopsy done at a different hospital, and it was a week before I got results. So how long it takes really depends on where you are at. Sometimes at a breast center, you will find out that day. So yes, it really just depends.
Just remember that worrying now is not going to change the results later. So try not to worry until you know there is something to stress about
. (I know... much easier said than done!)
Take care, and i hope your clusters are benign. Let us know how it goes.
Hugs...
BEV
Bev
Breast Cancer forum moderator
Posts.Title: needle core biopsy

Posts.Content:
Cancerous cells are cancerous cells. The pathologist will be looking at you biopsy on a cellular level. Breast cancer is breast tissue where the cells have run amok. So I wouldn't be concerned that the pathologist won't be able to tell the difference. I would be more concerned about
 the "he thinks" part. Either he got the tissue from the lump or he didn't. Please make sure that your doctor is aware of what you went through with this biopsy. If there is the slightest chance he missed the lump, I would want a surgical biopsy just to be sure.
Hugs...

Posts.Title: nerves

Posts.Content:
If a mammogram shows a nodule, and compression views show a nodule, then I would feel pretty sure that there is a nodule. Usually compression views are done to verify an abnormal finding on a mammogram. Ultrasound has definite limitations. It doesn't have good spatial resolution, so better detail is found in a mammogram. An ultrasound is only as effective as the technologist is skilled. It may not pick up a deeply seated mass. Ultrasound typically doesn't pick up microcalcifications. And imaging depends on the contrast between the mass and the surrounding breast tissue. 
Hope this helps. Are they recommending a biopsy at this point? 
Hugs...
BEV

Posts.Content:
Lots of call backs get posted! So there are lots of stories with happy endings. Glad to hear that has been a comfort to you. As to when is the best time to do a mammogram, there are mixed opinions and conflicting studies. Some say that the beginning of the menstrual cycle is best, because breast tissue is less dense. Some say that is the worst time, because the breasts are more tender, and the technicians don't "flatten" the breast as much because the patient complains of pain. Some say it really doesn't matter. 
Let us know how your callback goes.

Posts.Title: 25 Years old - Family HX of breast and ovarian CA - Dr. found lump, does not show up on ultrasound

Posts.Content:
Oh, Lmarie... it is so hard, I know. You know, when I was going through treatment, the most important thing to me was to keep my life as "normal" as possible. Some days, all I could do was put one foot in front of the other to keep going, but that's what I did. And I tried to keep a smile on my face and humor on my tongue, because otherwise I might just cry and scream and fall apart. I did the same as you, I went out and got very long hair whacked off short before it fell out, went wig shopping... my hubbie went with me, and I let him pick out my new hair. Oh, my, it was some big hair! Letting him pick was probably not the best decision I ever made! But he thought I looked beautiful in it, so what the heck! I was always smashing it down, and he was always fluffing it up. It really didn't matter, because the only time I wore the thing was when I was at work. Sinead O'Connor was big then (I'm dating myself here!), so I could easily go out with the bald head and get mistaken for a teenager, especially when I was with my teenaged daughters! But initially, the loss of that long blonde hair that my husband loved so much was worse than losing the breast. 
I remember one of my doctors telling me, "we're thinking about
 the long term here, we're not even going to think about
 you leaving us anytime soon." I tried to keep that hope he had like a promise in my heart. And there were days that were bad, but there were days that were good as well. So you just have to get yourself through the bad days, and enjoy every minute of the good ones. Easier said than done, I know. It sounds kind of silly, but when I was down, I would tell myself that I could get hit by a bus tomorrow and be just as dead, so I shouldn't waste my time grieving over breast cancer. Might not work for everyone, but we all find our ways, no matter how ridiculous they sound to others, and we deal with it the best we can. 
Hugs to you!
BEV

It probably is a hematoma. And it won't necessarily be gone in three months, but should at least be decreasing in size. And in terms of breast cancer, 3 months is not a long time to wait. It takes years for a tumor to grow to the size where it can be seen on a mammogram, and about
 three more years to become palpable. So try not to worry that waiting is going to make things worse in the off chance that it is a tumor.
Glad you got some good news! Let us know how it goes.

Posts.Title: Lab called to come for follow-up

Posts.Content:
Not being in the medical profession, I can't really answer the "why" about
 Tamoxifen. I just know from studies I have read that it is more effective in post-menopausal women than pre-menopausal women, and it has often been used as the only treatment, besides surgery, for post-menopausal women. 
I have a history of atypical hyperplasia of the cervix. All of my paps came back with this dx for several years, and then suddenly started coming back as normal. I felt like I was just waiting for the other shoe to drop for those years. So I know how you feel!
You could always think about
 prophylactic mastectomy and reconstruction. I know I'm considering a hysterectomy because of a family history of ovarian cancer. It's not 100% protection from cancer, but chances are much lower.
Glad that, for now, all is well, though.
Hugs...

Posts.Title: Lump in Breast

Posts.Content:
I didn't have a DIEP flap, but had a TRAM flap reconstruction, which is a little different. What I found to be the main problem was that I was very small, and for the amount of skin that they had to remove to reconstruct the breast, it didn't leave much to pull together for my belly. It was weeks before I could lay flat on my back, and months before I could lay on my belly and prop on my elbows. It was about
 two years before I became completely free of that feeling that your sister describes. But I think it really depends on how much "extra" skin you have to "share."
My plastic surgeon's nurse was diagnosed a couple of years after I was... when I went in for my two-year check-up, she complained of the same feeling and wanted to know how long it would last... she was 6 mos. post-op. I reminded her that she was the one who had told me I would be back to my old self in 6-8 weeks! 
I hope your sister will ask for a referral to a good physical therapist. It never hurts to have a professional help with some stretches and myofacial release to minimize adhesions. Been there, didn't do that, and will always regret that I didn't insist they give me a referral.
Hope this helps...

Posts.Title: Upper abdomen larger following diep flap

Posts.Content:
Mammogram is not the be-all and end-all. Cancers are missed on mammograms, typically in younger women, though. However, a mammogram is not necessarily going to determine what this lump in the armpit is. They don't do mammograms on the armpit, they do mammograms on breasts. So it doesn't answer the question of why there is a lump in your mom's armpit. It just means that she probably doesn't have breast cancer.
Enlarged lymph nodes can indicate lots of different things, from infection to cancer. It could also be a cyst, in which case it is nothing to worry about
. Personally, I would want to know what, for sure, it is... lymph node or cyst. If it is a node, why is it enlarged? 
Hope this helps...
Hugs...

First of all, this may not be breast cancer, so don't bury yourself yet! I was kind of where you are 17 years ago. I had lost my own mother to cancer when I was 7. When I was 36, I found a lump in my breast that felt different, went to the doctor, he found a second lump, ordered a mammogram. Mammogram said all is well. No sign of cancer. Doctor insisted on a biopsy. Two types of invasive breast cancer later, the surgeon told me, "this is not the end of the world." Easy for him to say! I thought this was the beginning of the end for me. Did I mention that this was 17 years ago? Yes, I think I did. LOL
The good news is, this very well might not be a breast cancer. Cysts are not breast cancer. A sonogram will determine if a mass is fluid-filled. It could also be a fibroadenoma (benign breast tumor) that has been there for years, since you cannot feel it, even now. 
So try not to dig your grave until you know what is going on! I know how hard it is to watch someone you love die from this disease. We never want our loved ones to go through that. But they get through it. You have. I have. And fingers crossed, our children won't have to see either of us go out that way.
Let us know what you hear from your doctor. And try not to worry when you don't know if there is something to worry about
!

Posts.Title: Holiday is here

Posts.Content:
Okay, so what your report referring to is that it has metastasized to the lymph nodes (technically speaking, when there is cancer in the lymph nodes, it is considered "metastatic;" however, when we talk about
 "mets," we are referring to distant mets... to the bones, liver, lungs, brain). With 5/10 lymph nodes, I assume they did initial scans to determine whether or not there are any distant mets. So yes, I would think you should have the scans repeated at this point. Chemo is given in the hopes that it will kill any cancer cells that have escaped the lymphatic system; if it doesn't, then it can take years for few stray cells to grow to a size that it can be detected on a scan, if it isn't a particularly aggressive cancer. Many years ago, chemo was only supposed to buy us 5 years or so. Since they have been finding tumors earlier, survival rates have really gone up.
However... that still doesn't mean that your cancer is back! All you know, for sure, is that your CA 27-29 has gone up a bit. Some women with distant mets have numbers in the thousands! And several women I have known didn't have tumor markers rise until after they were already having symptoms (bone pain, for example). So have the scans, and then you'll have a better idea of what is going on.
Hope that helps...
Hugs...
BEV

Posts.Title: Very Scared- Got the Dreaded Call Back

Posts.Content:
I don't know where you live, but most larger hospitals have a breast center. They could probably refer you to someone who would be familiar with male breast cancer. Typically, breast cancer is not painful; however, this is not always the case. Do you have a family history of breast cancer? It is more common in men who have a family history of breast cancer (male or female) and is sometimes linked to the BRCA-2 genetic mutation (prostate cancer is also associated with BRCA-2. I didn't seek out genetic testing for breast cancer until my brother was diagnosed with prostate cancer). You mentioned also that you took drugs that are to reduce the size of the prostate. You didn't say what drugs you took, but I've read that Propecia or Proscar have been associated with increased risk of male breast cancer (as well as high grade prostate cancer-- as I said, my brother has had prostate cancer, so I know bit about
 it). 
So... please follow up on this and find out what you are dealing with. The risks you have are small, but if I were you, I would continue to be proactive with this. 
Glad to hear your bone scan was clear, by the way. Hope your surgery goes well. 
Let me know how things go!
BEV
Bev
Breast Cancer forum moderator
Posts.Title: male breast cancer

Posts.Content:
As far as path reports go, that is a pretty good report. ER/PR positive means that your cancer likes female hormones for fuel, so you can take hormone blockers, such as Tamoxifen or Arimidex. They are particularly effective for women who are post-menopausal (typically meaning over 55). HER-2 negative is also a bit better than positive, because it is typically less aggressive cancer, as your Grade 1 would indicate. So even though cancer is never "good," you have indications that your cancer could be easier to treat than other types might be. Since your father had breast cancer, of course, there is a higher likelihood that your cancer is genetic. How you go about
 dealing with that is a very personal decision. Many women who have genetic cancers choose to have a double mastectomy to minimize their chances of developing breast cancer in the other breast. So that is something to think about
. 
Hope this helps.
Hugs...
BEV

Posts.Content:
Not knowing what you're dealing with is really hard. My kids were about
 12 and 13 when I was dxed with breast cancer at 36, so I know just how you feel. If anything happened to me, I didn't know how my husband would ever be able to get them through the teenage years. My oldest had to take her private HS entrance exams while I was being wheeled into surgery for my mastectomy. I felt so sorry for her, but it was important that she did that, and she aced it, but still... it was awful knowing that she would be sitting there taking such an important test and I would be the big thing on her mind. I sat in her 8th grade graduation ceremony, bald and hot flashing like crazy, wondering if I would even live to see the next one go through her 8th grade graduation the following year, much less see them graduate from high school! I made it through all that, though, and trying to keep my life as normal as possible was critical, as far as I'm concerned. Not saying that I didn't have my pity parties, but I just kept putting one foot in front of the other until I got there. Both of my daughters have their Master's degrees now, and the older one is working on her PhD, the younger one concentrating on being a mom for now... and believe me, I plan to see that grandbaby through her PhD, if that is what she wants to do! LOL So time has really changed my perspective. I am so darned grateful for each and every day, now! Time is the only thing that eases that fear and turns hope into determination.
So sorry you are having to go through this. But gosh, the things you have been through! Do you have a shunt for the hydrocephaly? Or was it a Chiari malformation? That is really strange. 
Keep us up to date. Cancer is cancer. The emotional life impact, I think, is pretty much the same. We may talk about
 boobs a lot around here, but living is our biggest concern. You're welcome to stick around. 
Hugs...

Posts.Title: Complex breast cyst

Posts.Content:
Niki... women can have very lumpy breasts and not have breast cancer. If the ultrasound showed a cyst, then you can always have your doctor aspirate the cyst. Ultrasound is designed to differentiate fluid-filled masses from solid masses. Breast cancer tumors are solid masses. On very rare occasions in complex cysts, there can be cancerous cells in "sludge." Again, this is rare. The best way to be sure this is "just a cyst" is to aspirate the fluid and have it checked. 
If your doctor feels other lumps that are suspicious, that is something else. Because you are young, mammography doesn't always pick up cancerous lumps. (I was 36, and my mammogram missed two invasive cancers.) Your doctor should be a good judge of what is "normal" lumpiness and what is not. And if you do routine breast exams, you should be able to feel what is normal for you! (I knew that my cancers felt different from my usual lumpy, bumpy breasts).
So when you see your doctor, you need to find out specifically what other kinds of lumps the doctor feels. And talk about
 having the cyst aspirated. 
Hope this helps...
BEV

Breast Cancer forum moderator

Well, that is good news, then! Lobular cancer in situ is a bit of a misnomer. It is actually not cancer, but abnormal growth of cells in the lobules. Women with LCIS are a greater risk of developing breast cancer, and that risk is pretty significant (about
 20%, I think), so your friend may want to consider her options, which include more frequent screening, taking hormone blockers (I'm sure you probably know what fun that can be!), or having prophylactic mastectomies. 20/100 women may not sound like a lot, but when you break it down to 1/5, that's a pretty significant #.
Hope this helps.

Posts.Title: Hello everyone

Posts.Content:
Sorry to hear that you are having to join our group, but glad to hear you are being proactive by getting a second opinion. Good for you! 
I was 36 when I was diagnosed with invasive ductal and lobular breast cancer. I had two young girls (they are both grown women now, and not far from the age I was at diagnosis!) I had lost my own mother to cancer when I was 7, so telling my girls and my dad... the hardest thing I ever had to do! Because I had lost my own mom, I was pretty convinced that this was the beginning of the end for me. And yet, here I am, 17 years later, telling you about
 it and feeling grateful for every day of those 17 years. When my surgeon confirmed that I had cancer, he blithely announced that "this is not the end of the world." And I remember thinking, "Yeah, that's easy for you to say. You're not the one with cancer. What are you going to say when you have to start taking out parts that I need?" So far, that hasn't happened! 
Don't beat yourself up for not doing breast exams. That cancer has been growing for years without being palpable, so the time it took you to find it is probably not greatly significant in the long run.
You can get through this; most of us have felt like we weren't strong enough more than once, but you'd be surprised how strong you can be! Cry when you need to, rant and rage when you need to, but just remember that every party is best if it ends while you're still enjoying it, and that includes "pity parties!"
Take care,and feel free to vent here. We've been there ourselves.
Hugs...

Posts.Title: tomoxifen

Posts.Content:
How did they stage your cancer to begin with? It is not uncommon to do liver, bone, and lung scans to determine staging. Not all liver function tests actually measure liver function... some measure inflammation. So the tests you may have had due to a med you were taking may not be the same tests that you oncologist would run. Does that make sense? If you do have a fatty liver, I don't think they have to avoid chemo altogether. They may just need to treat the fatty liver disease so that chemo doesn't do more damage to the liver. 
Your oncologist sounds like he has your long term health interests placed first in his treatment plan. If your staging at 1 is correct, postponing chemo to get your liver in better health is probably not going to impact your outcome significantly. 
Alcie's input is quite valid, as well. Not all stage 1 brca patients decide to have chemo, although most oncs recommend it as standard of care. You didn't mention how old you are or what other health issues you have (since you have been on medication for 17 years).
I hope this helps. Take care, and let us know how things go.

Congrats on the soon-to-be grandbaby! Aren't they just the best things ever? I only have one, but she is the light of my life. She may be the only one I get, but I take great pride in my grandpuppies, as well. 
Metastatic disease and mets are the same, yes. Not all oncologists follow tumor markers in patients who have no known mets because they are not completely reliable for diagnosing mets. Other things can affect tumor marker results and give "false positives." For women who are already diagnosed with mets, then tumor markers are a bit more effective in tracking progression of the mets. The distinction is whether or not the doctors know for fact that there are mets. If you have mets to the bones, for example, and they are doing chemo, and tumor markers drop significantly, then that can be a good sign. They aren't going to want to do a bone scan every month to see if the chemo is working. If that same hypothetical patient with bone mets suddenly has a large jump in numbers, that can be a bad sign. If those numbers continue to go up, they might do scans again to see if they are losing ground and need to change treatment strategies. 
The scans are the key to diagnosing mets. The tumor markers are only an indication of a possible problem. So have the scans done. 
Why did they think your original cancer was "most likely metastatic?" 
Hope this helps...

I found out I had cancer while I was still on the operating table, and the surgeon was closing his incision from my biopsy. The pathologist came and stood in the door, looking at me like he'd just shot Bambi's mother. When the nurse identified him as the pathologist, and he wanted to speak to the surgeon, I knew that this was not going to be good! The surgeon later told me that "this is not the end of the world," but it sure seemed like it at the time. I had lost my mother to cancer when I was 7, and I couldn't help by wonder how old my own daughters would be, how much longer I would be there for them. That was 17 years ago. Two types of invasive cancer, lymph node involvement, mastectomy, reconstruction, and 9 rounds of chemo. I missed 6 weeks of work with my surgery, but I never missed a day of work throughout my chemo treatment. 
I would think that, IF this turns out to be cancer, then the surgeon will be able to recommend a good oncologist for you. I agree with Anne... I don't think a nurse practitioner should be dumping all of this on you. You should not have to be out shopping for oncologists and putting in FMLA papers. That's kind of hard to do without a diagnosis and a treatment plan in place.

Posts.Title: I found a large lump in my right breast.

Posts.Content:
Usually the second mammogram is done with compression views, so they can look at a specific area more closely. An ultrasound can tell the difference between a mass and a cyst, so if there is something on the compression views, they usually do an ultrasound to see if it is solid or fluid-filled. If the compression views show that the mammogram had a false area of concern, then there would be no need to do the US. Hope this helps...
BEV
Posts.Title: How often is a mammogram repeated along with ultrasound

Posts.Content:
Well, we'll take a cyst over a solid mass any day! When I think of simple cysts vs. complex cysts, I visualize them this way. Picture a glass of orange juice. A simple cyst would be like the "no pulp" juices... You take a drink, and it goes down nice and smooth. A complex cyst would be like the varieties with pulp in them. Some have more pulp, some have less, but when you look in the glass, you see "stuff" floating around, and when you take a drink, you feel the stuff as you sip it and swallow. With orange juice, we know what the "stuff" is... or at least we hope we do! With complex cysts, the "debris" could be lots of different things... very rarely, some of that "stuff" could be a stray cancer cell. It might be like finding a seed in your orange juice, instead of just pulp. So that is why they follow up in six months. 
This, of course is an extremely simplified analogy. But this is the typical route that most doctors follow with complex cysts. It really is probably nothing. But if they see changes in 6 months, then they probably would want to aspirate or biopsy. 6 months, in terms of breast cancer, is a very short time. It is a slow-growing cancer, for the most part. 
I've read estimates that about
 5 percent of cysts are classified as "complex." Of that 5 percent, less that 1/2 of a percent are turn out to have malignant cells. 
Are you having your screenings done at a breast center? If you are, talk to your doctor about
 ordering a "diagnostic" mammogram instead of a "screening" next time. They usually schedule diagnostics on a day when the radiologist is on site, and then he/she reads your mammogram while you wait. If they want follow-up compression views or ultrasounds, they will typically do it right then and there, rather than having to reschedule with them for another day. 
Hope this helps! And congrats on being the proud possessor of a cyst! LOL
Hugs...

Posts.Title: Breast Biopsy Microcalcifications

Posts.Content:
Hi, Mama...
This must be very scary for you and your daughter. Complex cysts are harder to differentiate from solid masses on ultrasound, which is why they want to make sure this is just a cyst. The main question is: what is inside? A needle aspiration will probably give you that answer, and an excision would not be necessary. If the fluid they draw out is questionable, then they could still order a surgical biopsy. It is not uncommon for young girls to have cysts or other lumps and bumps, dense breast tissue, or fibrocystic breast disease, which are all benign conditions and not precursors for breast cancer. It would be rare for a 13-year-old to have breast cancer, but that is no guarantee. So your doctors are being very thorough, and you can be thankful that they are! A lot of doctors poo-poo young women for their concerns and dismiss their lumps and bumps as "nothing to worry about
," without further investigation.
As far as which to choose, needle or surgical biopsy, only you, your daughter, and your surgeon can make that decision. If this is just a cyst, and you opt to have a needle aspiration, then the cyst will probably fill back up with fluid and reappear. On very rare occasions, an cancer is missed on needle aspiration. If you opt for a surgical excision, your daughter will be losing some breast tissue, and this could make her self-conscious about
 the look of her breasts as she continues to develop and mature. When chances are it is not cancer, and the excision would be overkill, then that might be a big sacrifice for a 13-year-old. 
Let us know how things go. We'll be thinking about
 you two and hoping for good results, no matter the method you choose.
Hugs to you both...
BEV

Posts.Title: I have a large hard lump and I'm really frightened...and I have questions

Posts.Content:
Well, I agree with the other responses about
 getting a new doctor. No one deserves to be treated like you were treated. I had what the call "fibrocystic breast disease" when I was young and cute and had two breasts (LOL). My breasts were lumpy and bumpy and sometimes, those lumps and bumps are extremely painful, other times they are not. I was given all kinds of advice, such as take A, avoid caffeine, go on birth control... none of those things worked for me, personally. Apparently, this does work for some women, according to doctors; however. I've never met any of those women! And for reference, fibrocystic breast disease is not consider a precursor to breast cancer, so that is good to know. Another good thing to know is that breast cancer is slow growing, compared to many other cancers. Most breast cancers are 8-10 years old before they can be detected on a mammogram, and of course, they can typically be detected by mammogram before they are palpable. So suggesting you try Vitamin A for a month is not as if the gyn is condemning you to a death sentence if you were to be diagnosed with breast cancer. If she is considering this could be a breast cancer, suggesting that you avoid becoming pregnant before you know what this is could even be plausible. Breast cancers are often hormone driven, and you probably know that pregnancy is a hormonal roller coaster for a woman. Medically, I don't think she is on totally shaky ground with anything. 
However, to not explain her reasoning to you or give you any information and to treat you as if you are not worth her time and effort are just plain inexcusable. Ask a friend, a co-worker, someone at church or at the gym for a good gyn and get a second opinion. Most insurances will cover. 
Let us know how it goes, okay?
Hugs...
BEV

Posts.Title: Breast Biopsy

Posts.Content:
Hi, LLL... Sorry you are having to come here to ask questions! So I'll try to give you some info on what is going on. There are often two types of mammography appointments; there are screening mammograms, where they typically have a technician take films, make sure they are good, and then a radiologist looks at them later, and there are diagnostic mammograms, where a radiologist (who is a Dr.) reads your films and orders any additional tests right there. Sometimes they will even do a biopsy at that appointment. 
So the questions that you ask here are the same ones you should ask the doctor. As long as there are no complications, a biopsy is not a big deal. You can typically go back to work the next day. It's what I'd call a "band-aid" surgery. Some doctors will give you results on the phone, some call you back in for an appointment. Ask your doctor how his office handles it. 
80% of the lumps that make it to biopsy are benign. So try not to worry too much. I know it's a big shock when even the possibility of cancer looms in your life, so you're entitled worry just a little bit. ;)
Let me know what the surgeon says. Hope all goes well for you.
Hugs...
BEV

Posts.Title: Happy New Year!

Posts.Content:
Janice is right, that is a tough one! My insurance pays 80% for major medical, then we pay 20% until we hit our maximum out of pocket, which is 2500.00 per person. So check out for sure how your major medical works. The good news is that it is the first of the year, so your deductible would be met for the whole year! Any elective procedures you have been putting off??? Small consolation, huh. What type of biopsy are they considering? A surgical biopsy would probably cost more, for instance, than a needle biopsy, but a surgical biopsy would give the most definitive answer. And typically insurance companies will have a negotiated cost for a procedure, so what the "cost" is, according to the breast center, may actually be lower when you find out what your insurance company's negotiated cost is. You can ask your insurance company for an estimate on the actual cost to you. I would also check out to see what someplace like the Komen Foundation could do to help, if it is really a significant financial hardship for you.
Please let us know what you find out. I always like to err on the side of caution, but when 80% of all biopsies are negative, it is harder to say, "have the biopsy."
Hugs...

Posts.Title: Found a large lump

Posts.Content:
Fibrocystic breasts doesn't really mean anything other than you have dense, lumpy breast tissue. It is not cancer related. The specks they are referring to would be microcalcifications, which are very common. They look like specks of salt scattered through the breast tissue. They compare your previous pics to determine if there are any clusters forming of these specks. Sometimes, but not always, this can be an indication of an early breast cancer. I'll repeat: sometimes! More often than not, it's nothing, but they are wanting to be on the safe side, especially with your family history. 
What was your mom's dx and outcome, by the way?
Hope this helps!
Hugs...

Posts.Title: Very Scared- Got the Dreaded Call Back

Posts.Content:
First of all, I'll say that any of the reconstructions have good and bad about
 them. I had a TRAM flap, myself. It is a hard procedure with several weeks of recovery (months before you feel anywhere close to normal, but weeks before you are functional). I have had back problems as a result of the TRAM (the TRAMs are the "guidewires" for the spine). Not everyone who has a TRAM-flap have the issues I have, but I would highly encourage you to see a good physical therapist to help you through the recovery. There is a lot of scarring, and I'm not thrilled about
 the scar from hip to hip. It is not "like a tummy tuck," as some doctors refer to it. I was told that hernias were a slight risk, but I've never had one, and I didn't have the surgical mesh put in, even. Hope things work out for the best for you.
Hugs...

Posts.Title: Breast Biopsy Microcalcifications

Posts.Content:
It is not at all unusual for younger women to have dense breasts. That's one of the reasons why they recently changed the recommendations for mammograms. Density can often hide tumors, as they "read" the same on the mammogram. This doesn't happen often, but I was one of those women it happened to. I had two tumors that were totally missed on mammogram (I was 36 at the time). Because the tumors were palpable, my doctor insisted on biopsies. That was life-saving for me. It doesn't sound like you have anything that would cause concern on your part. So your doctors are erring on the side of caution... wish all doctors would do that! Take comfort in knowing that they are going to make sure that they aren't missing something... and try not to worry so much! LOL
Hope all turns out well for you. Let us know how it goes.

Posts.Title: MAMOGRAM TEST

Posts.Content:
There are two types of mammogram appts. First, there is your screening mammogram. The tech looks at your films to make sure they turned out. The radiologist looks at the films later. If there is something they have questions about
, they do a callback. Then there is the diagnostic mammogram. The radiologist will typically read the films while you wait, and if there is an issue, they take more pics or do an ultrasound right then, and some places will even do a biopsy that same day. Hope this helps.

Posts.Content:
The most important thing is that you are comfortable with the plan, and obviously, since you are seeking a second opinion from a surgeon, you are not comfortable with the plan! Did they possibly refer to the lump as a "lipoma?" These often don't show up on mammogram or ultrasound. They are basically encapsulated fat that creates a lump similar to what you described. They often do a fine needle aspiration or a core biopsy just to be sure that it is, in fact, fat in the lump. Dense breast tissue is common for younger women, but it can hide a myriad of things, including cancerous lumps (I had two, and both were missed by mammography). So personally, I think you are wise to be getting a second opinion. Hope he agrees that this is nothing to be worried about
. Let me know how it goes!

Posts.Title: found a lump and first mammogram done....now??

Posts.Content:
I've been told that pre- and post-menopausal really isn't accurate, as they don't look at your hormone levels to establish where you are. Instead, they use age 50 and above as post-menopausal, under 50 as pre-menopausal. Several studies have shown that "post-menopausal" women with high hormone receptors do really well with hormone therapy. 
Personally, I was er/pr positive, but just barely, and I was pre-menopausal (36). When chemo put me into menopause, it really didn't matter... 36 is under 50, so for treatment purposes, I was still classified as "pre-menopausal." So didn't make a lot of sense for me to take hormones. 
BTW... You are the first person I've heard say that the isolated radiation has been suggested! I'm so excited to know that! Would love to hear how that goes for you, if you have it. 
Hope your next surgeon appointment goes well, too. 
Hugs...

Posts.Title: Palpable lump doesn't show on mammogram, ultrasound, or MRI.

Posts.Content:
Lifebear, have you thought about
 having genetic testing done? If this is not breast cancer, and it could very well be nothing, then your mom could be tested. If your family has a genetic link, then you could think about
 prophylactic mastectomy with reconstruction. 
I was dxed at 36 with 2 types of breast cancer. My mom died of cancer at 45, but I also have a cousin with breast cancer, an aunt with ovarian cancer, a brother with prostate cancer, another aunt with adenocarcinoma of the lung... the list goes on! I had the genetic testing done at my daughters' request, and... no gene. 
Since I was dxed, I have had a "mass" identified in my remaining breast through mammography. Went back... no mass. I've also had a mass removed that didn't show on mammogram that was benign. BTW, neither of my cancerous tumors showed up on mammogram. 
So try not to put the cart before the horse! You're thinking about
 chemo before you even know if there is a reason for it! Chemo is not a picnic, but I never missed a day of work because of chemo. They've got terrific drugs that deal with the side effects. 
So take a breath, as smurfy suggested, and try not to worry about
 all the "what-if's." Easier said than done, I know! And let us know how it goes.
Hugs...

Posts.Title: comfortable wigs

Posts.Content:
I don't say this to scare you, but I was right where you are 17 years ago. I was 36, found a lump that felt different from the usual, watched it through a couple of cycles, and there was no change. Went to a new family doctor (we had just moved), who also found the same small lump, as well as a second one, and some enlarged lymph nodes. He ordered my first mammogram, which showed nothing significant, but did note dense breast tissue. This is where our stories part. My new doctor called a surgeon, made me an appointment himself, and then called me and told me to go, even though I didn't see the need if the mammo said "no indication of cancer." (I learned later that as many as 30% of breast cancers aren't found on a mammogram, largely because of dense breast tissue.) The surgeon didn't think my little lumps were anything, didn't feel anything under the arm, but would do a biopsy because my doctor had been so insistent. I was diagnosed with two different types of invasive breast cancer before the surgeon had even finished closing the incision. When I had my mastectomy, there was also lymph node involvement. I love that family doctor! 
Now for the good news. Yes, odds are definitely on your side that this will be nothing. Enlarged lymph nodes can mean a lot of different things, only one of which is cancer. This is because the nodes act as "filters" for the lymphatic system and are often the first indication of cancerous invasion. But they are much more likely to be an indication of an infection. Lymph node involvement in breast cancer is fairly common, and it usually just means treatment needs to be more aggressive than if it is not present. (In other words... chemotherapy to destroy any stray cells that may have gotten by the "filtration system.") Even if this is cancer, the 6-8 months that have passed since your initial mammogram is not very long, in terms of most breast cancers, which are typically slow growing. So that is the good news.
As for a second opinion, I think it depends on how comfortable you feel with the doctor's recommendations after the digital mammo and us. If he recommends a biopsy, I wouldn't really find a need for a second opinion, I'd just go head and have it. A small price to pay for peace of mind. If he doesn't recommend a biopsy, I would want to feel that I had a clear and complete explanation of why there is a lump and why there are enlarged lymph nodes, and I would probably want a second opinion that concurs. 
I didn't know anyone with breast cancer 17 years ago, either. And if I had had a doctor who told me "it was nothing," I never would have even thought to ask for another opinion or insist on a biopsy. I didn't have the internet or support groups. So I'm glad I'm able to share my experience with you. Again, not to scare you, but just to let you know that you need to be your own best advocate and get the answers you need to feel comfortable and safe in your own body. 
Hope this helps...
Hugs...
BEV

Breast Cancer forum moderator

Posts.Content:
Microcalcifications are pretty common, and most of the time, they are of little concern. On mammograms, they look for clusters of these microcalcifications, which can be an indication of cancer. Clusters are not always cancerous. As your doctor said, chances are that it is benign. But there is that possibility that it could be. If it is cancer, it is often diagnosed as an early cancer, known as DCIS (ductal cancer in situ) or LCIS (lobular cancer in situ). 
A biopsy is really the best way to know what you are dealing with. Glad to hear that you have gone in for an "overhaul." 20 years is a long time to avoid doctors! Just don't wait another 20, okay? Let us know how it goes. Hoping your in that 80% bracket!

Go back to your doctor!

Posts.Title: (No Subject)

Posts.Content:
Complex cysts are more troublesome than simple cysts. Simple cysts are filled with fluid and show up easily as fluid-filled on an ultrasound. A complex cyst has more than one "pocket." If not all of the pockets are fluid-filled, then it is more difficult to "read" on an ultrasound. I think the radiologist is being very thorough. A needle aspiration is the usual course of action. If the results are inconclusive, then they will want to excise the cyst. Most of the time, complex cysts are fine. They are a bit more likely to have pre-cancerous or cancerous cells. But about
 80% of all biopsies are benign. Please let us know how it goes!
Hugs to your wife... and teach how to use that darned computer!

Posts.Title: Radiation nightmare!

Posts.Content:
Hi, Janice... hey, how did your reconstruction saga turn out? I remember it was quite an ordeal for you. Why are they insisting on the AI at this time? Personally, I was given a choice. I chose not to take them. I was young, I had very low positive ER/PR scores, and chemo put me into early menopause. There was no clear cut, "yes, you should take them," and most of the research at the time said there was no evidence that they would significantly benefit me, if they were of benefit at all. I know people who have taken them for a few years, stopped taking them, and then within a few months were dx'ed with mets. I know people who have been told they should take them for life and are doing fine. I know people who have never taken them and are doing fine. 
With AI's, I think age at diagnosis and ER/PR status are the most important factors. But most people I know who take them begin shortly after they finish other treatments. So again I'm wondering, why are they insisting now?

Posts.Title: NEED HELP TO UNDERSTAND BREAST ULTRASOUND REPORT

Posts.Content:
JM... just wanted to add that, typically, it takes a breast cancer lump 8-10 years to grow to a size where it can be seen on a mammogram... and a couple of years more to grow to a size where it is palpable. So 2 weeks is next to nothing, in the big picture. When we are first diagnosed, all we want is to get that thing out of our bodies, and 2 weeks can seem like an eternity. But it seems that the process is one of "hurry up and wait." Once she sees the surgeon, it could be weeks before she has follow-up surgery. Then there is a wait to get in to the radiologist or the oncologist. And another wait before the treatment begins. I had my mammogram on October 23, got in to a surgeon right away, then had to wait til Nov 11 to have a biopsy. Mastectomy wasn't until December 6, and the oncologist initially scheduled me for February. My hubby called them and threw a hissie-fit on the phone, so they got me in two weeks after surgery, and I had my first chemo on December 28. In retrospect, I wish I had put off chemo for a few more weeks, so that I could have had more healing time! But at the time, I was glad he had pushed. 
Waiting is hard, but it can have its benefits. You have time to research your options and think about
 what YOU want. 
Hope all goes well with your mom. Let us know!
Hugs...

So far, knock on wood, I've been fine. It really is a very personal choice, at the level you are at. If I had been told I was limiting my survival odds, I think I would have taken them, regardless of the side effects. You've got to do what is right for you, but I think you've been telling us for awhile now that you don't think this is right for you. You just have to be willing to look back and not regret the decision you make.
It's a tough one!

Yeah, there is a difference between mastectomy and lumpectomy, as far as recommendations for radiation are concerned. Harrington had a mastectomy. With lumpectomy, radiation is almost always recommended. Jo, I didn't think you were being flippant. I remember when I was diagnosed, my best friend said she wished it were her instead of me, she was old, she didn't need her boobs anymore, and on and on. Well, a couple of years later, she, too, was dx'ed with breast cancer, and someone we both knew said about
 the same thing to her. She was mad as a wet hen! I reminded her that she had said the same thing to me... she said, "Yeah, but back then I thought they just cut off your breast and that was the end of it. I didn't realize you could actually die from it!" That seems to be a common misconception. Unfortunately, my friend was one of those who lost the battle with this disease. I have a cousin who was dx'ed a couple of years ago. Her doctor has told her that she is "cured." When we have doctors out there pronouncing cures when facts say there isn't a cure... You look a tLaw1015's post. Her mom was 15 years seemingly cancer-free, and now has mets. There's a dose of reality for anyone who thinks they are cured, I guess.

So I ended up having two types of invasive breast cancer in the same breast, and it had already spread to the lymph nodes. That was 16 years ago. I don't think I would be alive today had my family doctor not been even more stubborn than I am!

Posts.Title: Thank you for sharing

Posts.Content:
I never took any of the anti-estrogen drugs, but went into menopause from the chemo at 36. Awful hot flashes. Covers on, covers off, all night. Sometimes some of the antidepressants will help, and different ones work for different people. I know people who swear by Paxil, others by Zoloft or Wellbutrin. I tried lots of them, none of which helped, until we tried Effexor. I saw a huge difference in a matter of days. I think any of the aromatase inhibitors that block estrogen are going to result in hot flashes. 
Let us know if you find something that works for you!
Hugs...

Posts.Title: (No Subject)

Posts.Content:
Congrats on the 14months... and for fighting for that biopsy! I had the opposite problem... I was very thin, and they had to take a lot of belly and both muscles to make one breast mound. Recovery was long! Haven't had any trouble gaining weight since hitting menopause during chemo, though! LOL Really, I don't know "how big" they can make them. After carrying around double D's, I would think you would want a smaller pair now, but to each his own. I know I've seen some pretty large TRAMs. I know my friend, MK, who is a co-moderator here, had a fairly large breast constructed through TRAM. I don't know if she would want to share cup size! 
You are right, though. Losing some weight prior to the surgery would be a good thing. It is not an easy surgery to go through or to recover from. 
I don't know what motivation I can give you if you are not motivated to do this for yourself. Do they have you on thyroid replacement? And is it an adequate dose? I try to be a low-carb eater these days, and when I stick to it, it works. I don't think I could eat that way if I didn't have Splenda! I knocked 40 pounds off my hubby in 3 months for a necessary surgery by putting him on the low-carb plan. We had Splenda sweets every day... cheesecake, sundaes, crepes, lots of whipped cream, etc... so it isn't a starvation diet by any means. I always recommend people try it, if the haven't yet. Much easier than counting calories and cutting fat out of your diet. Some people think it is not so good for you, but I eat lots more "good stuff" on low-carb than I did before I ate that way.
Don't know if that helps, but hope so!
Hugs....

Posts.Title: mouse shaped nodule?

Posts.Content:
Grandpuppy turned out to be just fine. Her tumor was benign. Pudgie did not have such good news. He had a very large osteosarcoma that was displacing his heart and his trachea. We brought him home for a week and tried to keep the fluids in check with diuretics. They weren't doing a hot job of it. So we spoiled him rotten for a few days (he never lost his appetite!) and said our goodbyes. He was a wonderful beast of a dog, and his loss has left a very large hole in our lives.
Sasha is back to her old self... ornery little thing! Took our retriever out and ditched her in the woods. Faye is a retired seeing eye dog, and let me tell you, it must have been the blind leading the blind, because that dog couldn't find her way out of a paper bag! She was trying to get a drink from a neighbor's pool (distant neighbor, at that!), fell in, and couldn't get herself out. So our neighbor had to get in and haul her out. OMG. She and Sasha aren't allowed out at the same time, because this is the second time Sasha has ditched her! But Sasha scooted out the door on me, and the rest you know now. Life goes on at my house.
Love and hugs to all the breast friends...

Posts.Title: comfortable wigs

Posts.Content:
Your doctor is so right to tell you that a biopsy is the only way to know for sure. Suspicions are just that. My first mammogram missed not one, but two invasive cancers with lymph node involvement. I got the letter stating my mammogram was normal a few days after the biopsies. My intent is not to scare you, but to let you know that, in my situation, waiting would have not been in my best interest. Will canceling the biopsy and waiting six months decrease your level of anxiety and fear? Not nearly as much as hearing your doctor say, "I was right... it's not cancer." And even if it were to turn out to be cancer, "We got it very early" would be great news! 
Hope you will follow through with the biopsy! Let us know.
Hugs...
